message_1: Find the position, size, and nature of the image formed by a concave mirror of focal length 10 cm when an object is placed 20 cm in front of it.
message_2:
To find the position, size, and nature of the image formed by a concave mirror, we can use the mirror formula and magnification formula.

Mirror formula: 1/f = 1/u + 1/v
Magnification formula: m = -v/u

Here, f is the focal length of the mirror, u is the object distance (distance of the object from the mirror), and v is the image distance (distance of the image from the mirror). The magnification, m, is the ratio of the height of the image to the height of the object.

Given:
Focal length, f = -10 cm (concave mirror has a negative focal length)
Object distance, u = -20 cm (object is placed in front of the mirror, so the distance is negative)

Now, we can use the mirror formula to find the image distance (v):

1/f = 1/u + 1/v
1/(-10) = 1/(-20) + 1/v

Multiplying both sides by -20v to eliminate fractions:

-2v = -v + 20
v = 20 cm

The image distance is positive, which means the image is formed on the same side as the object, and it is a real image.

Now, let's find the magnification (m):

m = -v/u
m = -20 / (-20)
m = 1

The magnification is 1, which means the size of the image is the same as the size of the object.

In summary, the image formed by the concave mirror is a real image, located 20 cm in front of the mirror, and has the same size as the object.
